topics.body: How does one even _begin_ reading comics?
topics.author: 5041b54f7f123b77af00a442

topics.body:
"@And Brother I Hurt People":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53d1300e6368725018760000#post_53d1300e6368725018760000

step 1: grab the comic
step 2: grab alcohol
step 3: drink the alcohol
step 4: pour the alcohol in a container
step 5: put the comic in the container
step 6: burn it.
step 7: do the same to all comics you have
step 8: do something more interesting
topics.author: 5154c5237f123bcd580002fc

topics.body:
"@And Brother I Hurt People":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53d1300e6368725018760000#post_53d1300e6368725018760000
[bq="And Brother I Hurt People"]How does one even _begin_ reading comics?[/bq]
Volume #1
!http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-TPpcxkSQMjc/Ui6LufLCk5I/AAAAAAAADnY/KVfa43VtwQ4/s1600/rimshot.jpg!



And now for your daily science post:
So I was reading up on a Oxford study into automatization of the workforce and here's something interesting: apparently nearly half of all types of jobs in the next two decades will be automated and no longer require human workers; what I mean by this is that jobs like surgeons, farmers, burger flippers at McDonalds and such will be eliminated because robots will take over the jobs.

Is this a bad thing?  Depends really on how society reacts.  On the one hand you have massive amounts of people losing jobs, but on the other hand you have ever increasing drops in prices for good and services so while a lot of people are going to lose their jobs on the same turn it's going to promote buying goods and services due to ever increasing price slashes.  Personally I think what will probably happen is ever increasingly less hours worked on average, more part time workers and those jobs lost being offset; so while yes it's a bad thing chances are the lower prices for goods and services will offset it.  To put it simply more part time workers, but on the same token far cheaper products.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600
